descriptions.content:
Tibetan verbs fall into two main classes: volitional verbs and non-volitional verbs. The grammar of European languages does not make this opposition between volitional and non-volitional. However, in terms of vocabulary the differentiation can be observed. For example, “hear” and “see” are non-volitional, while “listen” and “look” are volitional.

Within each of these two main classes, a distinction is made between transitive verbs and intransitive verbs. Transitive verbs require an object, whereas intransitive verbs do not.

There are, then, altogether four basic classes of verbs: non-volitional intransitive, volitional intransitive, non-volitional transitive, and volitional transitive.

Table: Examples of the Four Verb Classes

 

Volitional

བྱ་ཚིག་རང་དབང་ཅན་  

Non-Volitional

བྱ་ཚིག་གཞན་དབང་ཅན་  

Transitive

བྱ་ཚིག་ཐ་དད་པ་

 

ལྟ་ “Look”

ཉན་ “Listen”

བཟོ་ “Make”

མཐོང་ “See”

གོ་ “Hear”

ཧ་གོ་ “Understand”

Intransitive

བྱ་ཚིག་ཐ་མི་དད་པ་

ཉལ་ “Lie down”

ལང་ “Get up”

འགྲོ་ “Go”

ན་ “Be sick”

ཤི་ “Die”

དྲག་ “Recover”
